title: Burberry’s Spring 2017 Runway Show Doubles Down on Knitwear and Denim - Vogue
text: Burberry’s Spring 2017 Runway Show Doubles Down on Knitwear and Denim February 20, 2017 9:00 PM by Steff Yotka Photo: Yannis Vlamos / Indigital.tv At London Fashion Week today, Christopher Bailey presented Burberry’s second see-now-buy-now ready-to-wear collection to an audience filled with celebrities (hello, Kris Wu!) and longtime Burberry muses like Naomi Campbell and Lily Donaldson. Set in the Makers House, where Anna Calvi performed live and artwork by Henry Moore dotted the runway, the Burberry show was a true spectacle—and yet Bailey ensured that his artful clothing was the real star. Here, we recap the fashion highs of the show. Check Vogue Runway later today for Chioma Nnadi’s full review of Burberry’s Spring 2017 women’s and men’s collection. Photo: Yannis Vlamos / Indigital.tv The Knits Among the early looks in today’s show were a series of asymmetrical cable knits for men and women. In classic ivory, the sweaters called to mind classic Irish fisherman knits, but with a modern, arty twist. Photo: Yannis Vlamos / Indigital.tv The Trenches It wouldn’t be a Burberry show without trenchcoats, would it? During Bailey’s 16 years at the house, he’s redone the brand’s staple in shining satins, ruched bubble shapes, and transparent rubber. This season’s iterations were more understated, arriving in beige and sky blue with oversize collars and long, draped sleeves. Photo: Yannis Vlamos / Indigital.tv The Arty Prints Henry Moore’s art was more than just a set piece at the Burberry show. Shirts and sweatshirts featured hand-drawn cartoons of screaming faces and reclining humans that echoed the sanguine shapes of Moore’s work but with a brighter palette. Photo: Yannis Vlamos / Indigital.tv The Denim Denim is a rare sight on a Burberry runway. Today, the fabric was made into wide-leg jeans for women and a workwear-like jacket and pants ensemble for men with engineer striping.
